facts.text: Advocate-General of Madhya Pradesh filed complaint on January 13, 1953, against appellant and three others under s. 282 of Indian Companies Act and ss. 465 and 477A of Indian Penal Code.
Proceedings commenced in 1954 before a Magistrate.
On May 18, 1955, proceedings transferred to Special Magistrate Shri K. L. Pandey at Nagpur.
Special Magistrate commenced recording of evidence on July 4, 1955.
Criminal Procedure Code Amendment Act 26 of 1955 received assent of President on August 12, 1955, and came into force on January 2, 1956.
On January 14, 1956, appellant made application to Special Magistrate claiming right to appear as witness under s. 342A of amended Code.
Special Magistrate dismissed appellant's application on February 2, 1956, in Criminal Case No. I of 1955.
Appellant's revision to Nagpur High Court in Criminal Revision No. 150 of 1956 dismissed on May 28, 1956.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether provisions of s. 342A of the amended Criminal Procedure Code apply to pending prosecution where recording of evidence had commenced prior to commencement of the Amending Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellant claimed right to appear as witness on his own behalf under s. 342A of amended Code in disproof of charges.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 342A CrPC (as inserted by s. 61 of Amending Act)

respondent_arguments.text: Proceedings pending before Special Magistrate to be governed by unamended Code; s. 342A not applicable as per clause (c) of s. 116 of Amending Act, which requires such trials to be continued as if the Act had not been passed.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s. 116(c) of CrPC Amendment Act 26 of 1955

court_reasoning.text: No vested right in any course of procedure; change in procedure operates retrospectively unless excluded.
court_reasoning.key_observation: General principle: procedural amendments apply to pending cases.

court_reasoning.text: s. 116 of Amending Act excludes specific provisions (ss. 4(w), 207A, 251A, 260) for inquiries/trials where evidence recording began before commencement, but s. 342A (in Chapter 24) not excluded.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Interpretation avoids conflict; 'save as aforesaid' makes other provisions applicable to pending proceedings.

court_reasoning.text: High Court erred in construing clause (c) to exclude all provisions; only specified sections excluded.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s. 342A applicable as not expressly excluded.

holdings.text: s. 342A of amended CrPC available to appellant; entitled as competent witness for defence to testify in disproof of charges.

precedents_cited.case_name: Colonial Sugar Refining Co. Ltd. v. Irving
precedents_cited.relevance: No vested right in procedure; procedural changes operate retrospectively.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure (Amended by Act 26 of 1955)
statutes_cited.relevance: s. 342A makes accused competent witness for defence; s. 116 specifies applicability to pending proceedings, excluding certain sections but applying others.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Deals with competent witnesses; inapplicable to accused under unamended CrPC s. 342.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: No accused shall be compelled to be witness against himself.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside the orders of the Special Magistrate and Nagpur High Court, holding that s. 342A applies and appellant is entitled to appear as a competent witness for the defence.
outcome.relief_granted: Appellant entitled to give evidence under s. 342A.

key_quotes.text: "No person has a vested right in any course of procedure. He has only the right of prosecution or defence in the manner prescribed for the time being..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Establishes retrospective effect of procedural amendments.

key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Direct holding on applicability to pending case.

key_quotes.text: "The High Court was therefore in error and the appellant is entitled... as a competent witness for the defence to testify in disproof of the charges..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
